Refer to this link for build results (access rights to CI server needed): 
https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-PullRequestBuilder/1381/
LGTM üëç
cc @niketanpansare, @deroneriksson, @nakul02, @frreiss, @mboehm7, @prithvirajsen, @bertholdreinwald

@bdwyer2 I agree that this is definitely useful.  I need to think about whether there is a way to do it without affecting the regular usage of the existing scripts.  Or perhaps we can just update it with the upcoming 1.0 release.
in general, I think it's fine to graduate this nn library in 1.0 (predicated on sufficient performance testing), but why not put it into /scripts/algorithms/nn?

Putting it in scripts allows the source statements to utilize package-style imports (SYSTEMML-1476) with nn as the base from the jar, such as `source("nn/examples/mnist_softmax.dml") as mnist_softmax`
LGTM. Thank you for this great contribution to the project @dusenberrymw.

@nakul02 I've added a new `mnist_lenet_distrib_sgd-train-dummy-data.dml` training file that uses generated dummy data.  Please see the comments at the top of the file for the info, but essentially you can control the number of examples (train, val, test), image size (height, width, channels), number of target labels, batch size, number of parallel batches (i.e. number of GPUs), number of and epochs (i.e. full passes over the entire dataset).  They all have sensible defaults.

It can be run from within the `examples` folder with the following command:

```
spark-submit --master local[*] --driver-memory 10G --conf spark.driver.maxResultSize=0 --conf spark.rpc.message.maxSize=128 $SYSTEMML_HOME/target/SystemML.jar -f mnist_lenet_distrib_sgd-train-dummy-data.dml -nvargs N=1024 Nval=512 Ntest=512 C=1 Hin=28 Win=28 K=10 batch_size=32 parallel_batches=8 epochs=10 out_dir=model/mnist_lenet
```
LGTM :+1:
Thanks @dusenberrymw, will try this out for testing of the GPU parfor.

Thanks, I'll merge this.  The plan is to start running all algorithms from `scripts`, rather than from inside `scripts/algorithms`.  Therefore, `nn`, `algorithms`, `datagen`, etc. become DML packages that can be sourced from other DML scripts.
Build successful

Refer to this link for build results (access rights to CI server needed): 
https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-PullRequestBuilder/1384/
@nakul02 I've rebased the code onto master and made a few updates.  Can you please try this?

Generate data, train, and predict example using nn library in Spark Shell:
```
import org.apache.sysml.api.mlcontext._
val ml = new MLContext(spark)
val mnist_lenet = ml.nn.examples.Mnist_lenet
val data = mnist_lenet.generate_dummy_data
val t = mnist_lenet.train(data.x,data.y,data.x,data.y,data.c,data.hin,data.win,1)
mnist_lenet.predict(data.x,data.c,data.hin,data.win,t.w1,t.b1,t.w2,t.b2,t.w3,t.b3,t.w4,t.b4)
```

Examples of function display:
```
// display function contents to end of comments
mnist_lenet.generate_dummy_data_
// display full function contents
println(mnist_lenet.generate_dummy_data__)
```

Example using a scripts/algorithms/A.dml file containing:
```
add = function(matrix[double] m, int num) return (matrix[double] n) { n = m + num }
sub = function(matrix[double] m, int num) return (matrix[double] n) { n = m - num }
mult = function(matrix[double] m, int num) return (matrix[double] n) { n = m * num }
```
Spark Shell:
```
val x = Array(Array(1.0, 2.0), Array(3.0, 4.0))
val a = ml.algorithms.A
for (i <- 1 to 3) { a.add(x,i).toDF.show }
for (i <- 1 to 3) { a.sub(a.mult(a.add(x,i),i),i).toDF.show }
```
Build successful

thanks for working on this; couple of high-level comments:
1) the up-to-date issue is https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/SYSTEMML-1325
2) the purpose of this issue is to consolidate the compilation chain from script to runtime program to create consistency and fix a couple of existing bugs, not just the actual execute 
3) I would recommend to remove the old mlcontext first in order to avoid unnecessary updates
4) further, please start from DMLScript's compilation chain as this is the only feature-complete compilation chain and thus, the ground truth.

Furthermore, it would be great to design a configurable compilation chain first, implement it as a new class, and subsequently replace all duplicated compilation chains (for that the new chain need to be sufficiently flexible to allow a one-line invocation from mlcontext/jmlc/dmlscript/debug)
Build successful

Refer to this link for build results (access rights to CI server needed): 
https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-PullRequestBuilder/1397/

>> I would recommend to remove the old mlcontext first in order to avoid unnecessary updates

I am not sure the right protocol here. Should this be discussed on the mailing list before removing an API ? If this is not required as the old MLContext has been deprecated for a while, I can remove the old MLContext as part of this PR. Else, I suggest that it should be addressed in a separate PR. 

>> the purpose of this issue is to consolidate the compilation chain from script to runtime program to create consistency and fix a couple of existing bugs, not just the actual execute
>> further, please start from DMLScript's compilation chain as this is the only feature-complete compilation chain and thus, the ground truth.
>> Furthermore, it would be great to design a configurable compilation chain first, implement it as a new class, and subsequently replace all duplicated compilation chains (for that the new chain need to be sufficiently flexible to allow a one-line invocation from mlcontext/jmlc/dmlscript/debug)

I agree, this PR doesnot resolve the JIRA. In fact, this PR is deliberately scoped to only address the execute() part of the compilation chain for two reasons:
- The inconsistencies in execute() part could results in significant bugs when used via MLContext.
- I do not have free cycles (at least for next few weeks) to consolidate the entire compilation chain.

If you prefer, I can rename the PR to SYSTEMML-1047  and SYSTEMML-1506 and we can merge it in.  I am also OK with closing this PR if you or someone else wants to redesign the entire chain; in which case, this PR will just get in the way :)

@akchinSTC @mboehm7 I really like having the build results displayed (for both passing and failing) on the PR page. But perhaps the two messages "Build successful" and "Refer to this link..." could be consolidated into a single message.
@dusenberrymw @bdwyer2 The above will not break the existing script. I believe it is returning extra matrixes so it should be safe
cc @deroneriksson

@dusenberrymw I don't see any tests in the project that test Cox.dml (including scripts/perftest/runAll.sh, where there is a comment where the test should be), so I don't think this change would break anything.

Is line 213 ok (`write (S_str, fileS, format = fmtO)`)?

Is this comment still applicable to the matrices (vs. the original string format)?
```
# Two log files containing a summary of some statistics of the fitted model:
 # 1- File S with the following format 
 #	- line 1: no. of observations
 #	- line 2: no. of events
 #   - line 3: log-likelihood 
 #	- line 4: AIC
 #	- line 5: Rsquare (Cox & Snell)
 #	- line 6: max possible Rsquare
 # 2- File T with the following format
 #	- line 1: Likelihood ratio test statistic, degree of freedom, P-value
 #	- line 2: Wald test statistic, degree of freedom, P-value
 #	- line 3: Score (log-rank) test statistic, degree of freedom, P-value
```

LGTM, pending test suite completion (https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-PullRequestBuilder/1403/).

I tried NNTest and it worked great in Eclipse. This is a really great contribution for a couple reasons:
1) DML is being tested by DML (wrapped by Java)
2) I believe it's the first integration tests of scripts in our actual main scripts directory

One small comment. You can probably remove the `JavaSparkContext sc` field.
BTW I believe the additional location check in ParserWrapper is a good idea too.
Thanks, @deroneriksson.  I made the small cleanup as well.
Build successful

well, I could indeed imagine such as speedup as we're currently only calling out to commons-math because solve is by far not the bottleneck in ALS or LinregDS (only called for tiny matrices in the rank or number of features).
@mboehm7 - understood, still this PR provides value. The more operations in a loop that are on the GPU, the lesser the ping pong of data between host and device memories.

sure - this is absolutely fine; I'm just setting the expectations straight: for example for LinregDS, it's called once and is even for 1k features in the sub-second range. However, down the road, once we have a distributed solve, there might be more algorithms that could benefit from it.

distributing `solve` is a great idea. In fact, that is exactly what @iyounus is trying to do through DML using the single node builtin functions `qr`, `cholesky` and `lu`. I think #368 is some work towards that. There was an earlier version which used `parfor` to do the distribution.

@iyounus @dusenberrymw 
Can we go ahead and merge this to staging as a first step towards its eventual move to a top-level algorithm?

@iyounus @nakul02 @dusenberrymw 
Any chance we can go ahead and merge this to staging? If there are optimizer issues, perhaps they will be more likely to be dealt with if the algorithm has been merged to the staging directory.

@iyounus @dusenberrymw 
Any chance we can merge this to staging? If further updates are needed, additional pull requests can be created. I'm a little concerned that the SystemML project is not merging in enough DML contributions. New contributions are valuable to users and potentially stress the engine in different ways.

@iyounus @dusenberrymw 
I'm not an ML expert but I'm inclined to merge this contribution. It's been here for 3 months and given the high quality of the DML, we should move it to staging.
LGTM. If this is GPU, I feel @nakul02 and @niketanpansare are the owners of this area and need to merge and move forward for our 1.0.0 release.
thanks @deroneriksson !

As this PR has been here for 9 months(!) and @dusenberrymw and I can't seem to stimulate any further conversation regarding the PR, it should be closed.

@lresende Are you admin on the project on GitHub so that you can close this PR? I can always add a "Closes #..." to another PR to close this PR, but that is a bit of a hack.
I've checked the results from gpu solve and these are correct.

Hi @niketanpansare, I believe the full Apache license doesn't need to be included in its own section in src/main/python/LICENSE. It can be added to section that mentions Apache Wink.

In addition, the caffe and tensorflow files appear to be added to the main jar. If this is so, these need to be mentioned in:
src/assembly/bin/LICENSE
src/assembly/distrib/LICENSE
src/assembly/inmemory/LICENSE
src/assembly/jar/LICENSE
src/assembly/standalone-jar/LICENSE
BTW this is why I think we should remove "distrib". We have way too many LICENSE files to manage right now. :-)
6 month check-in. What is the status of this PR? Merge or close?
6(!) month check-in. What's the status of this PR? Merge or close?

Current this PR is up to:
Conversation 102 | Commits 26 | Files changed 51

It has been open since January. We should consider merging or closing before the 1.0.0 release with significant time for testing if it is merged.

@bertholdreinwald @frreiss @mboehm7 @nakul02

Refer to this link for build results (access rights to CI server needed): 
https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-PullRequestBuilder/1420/

@deroneriksson I absolutely agree - something like this needs to go in at least a month or two before a release. Let's resolve all remaining build and deploy issues and then bring it in (along with a testsuite that checks for existing libraries and only runs if they are available; of course we should install it on our build server).

I think this can be merged to staging. Initially there was a bug in systemml that didn't allow this algorithm to work but that has been fixed. It still needs some testing but I don't think any major changes are required here.

I would like to get some input from other people on this. My understanding is that this may not scale at all or at least will perform much worse than the tree based implementations that are available. So, we may just drop this. BTW, due to some bugs in systemml, I was never able to run with larger data set. But those bugs have been fixed.

I think we can just close this. I implemented this based on a recent paper but now I think this method is not very beneficial when it comes to scaling and that paper was somewhat misleading. So at this moment we can close this. This require some more thinking.
Great! Thank you @iyounus. I'll merge to staging.

@deroneriksson @mboehm7  I think this PR has addressed all the deploy/build issues on Linux. Remaining issues can be addressed later as bugfixes in subsequent PR.

@bertholdreinwald @nakul02  After spending significant amount of time on trial and error for Mac (and Windows), I think we should only support BLAS on Linux machines for following reasons:
- GNU OpenMP is not enabled by default on Mac, and it requires either downloading GCC or using experimental clang-openmp.
- GNU OpenMP is not supported by Intel MKL on Mac. Hence we see potential degradation due to switching between GNU OpenMP and Intel OpenMP for operations such as conv2d_backward_data.
- To compile with only Intel OpenMP, we need to buy an Intel Compiler. GCC or Clang doesnot allow us to compile with Intel OpenMP.
- Even if we buy Intel OpenMP, the problem remains with OpenBLAS+OpenMP support.

Since we have already have cmake setup in place, we can always support BLAS on Mac and Windows in future when OpenMP related issues are resolved. 

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

For your reference, please see below for instructions for compiling BLAS-enabled SystemML on Mac and Windows:

## 64-bit x86 Windows
- Install MKL or Download the OpenBlas Binary
- Install Visual Studio Community Edition (tested on VS 2017)
- Use the CMake GUI, select the source directory, the output directory
- Press the `configure` button, set the `generator` and `use default native compilers` option
- Set the `CMAKE_BUILD_TYPE` to `Release`, this sets the appropriate optimization flags
- By default, `USE_INTEL_MKL` is selected, if you wanted to use OpenBLAS, unselect the `USE_INTEL_MKL`, select the `USE_OPEN_BLAS`.
- You might run into errors a couple of times, select the appropriate library and include files/directories (For MKL or OpenBLAS) a couple of times, and all the errors should go away.
- Then press generate. This will generate Visual Studio project files, which you can open in VS2017 to compile the libraries.
The current set of dependencies are as follows:
- MKL: mkl_rt.dll (for functions: `mkl_set_num_threads` and `cblas_dgemm`).
- OpenBLAS: libopenblas.dll (for functions: `openblas_set_num_threads` and `cblas_dgemm`).
- Visual C OpenMP: vcomp140.dll (for function: `omp_get_thread_num`).
- Visual C Runtime: vcruntime140.dll (for functions: `memcpy` and `memset`).
- API-MS-WIN-CRT-ENVIRONMENT-L1-1-0.DLL, API-MS-WIN-CRT-RUNTIME-L1-1-0.DLL and API-MS-WIN-CRT-HEAP-L1-1-0.DLL (for functions: `malloc` and `free`).
- KERNEL32.dll
If you get an error `Error LNK1181 cannot open input file 'C:/Program.obj'`, 
you may have to use quotation marks around the path in Visual Studio project properties.
- Property Pages > C/C++ > General > Additional Include Directories
- Property Pages > Linker > Command Line
If you get an error `CMake Error at cmake/FindOpenBLAS.cmake:71 (MESSAGE): Could not find OpenBLAS`,
please set the environment variable `OpenBLAS_HOME` or edit the variables `OpenBLAS_INCLUDE_DIR` and `OpenBLAS_LIB`
to point to the `include` directory and `libopenblas.dll.a` respectively.
If you get an error `install Library TARGETS given no DESTINATION!`, you can comment `install(TARGETS systemml preload LIBRARY DESTINATION lib)` 
in CMakeLists.txt and manually place the compiled dll in the `src/main/cpp/lib` directory.
## 64-bit x86 Mac
The version of clang that ships with Mac does not come with OpenMP. `brew install` either `llvm` or `g++`. The instructions that follow are for llvm:
1. Intel MKL - CMake should detect the MKL installation path, otherwise it can specified by the environment variable `MKLROOT`. To use (with clang):
```
mkdir INTEL && cd INTEL
CXX=/usr/local/opt/llvm/bin/clang++ CC=/usr/local/opt/llvm/bin/clang LDFLAGS=-L/usr/local/opt/llvm/lib CPPFLAGS=-I/usr/local/opt/llvm/include cmake  -DUSE_INTEL_MKL=ON -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Release ..
make install
```
### (with gcc-6):
```
mkdir INTEL && cd INTEL
CXX=g++-6 CC=gcc-6 cmake  -DUSE_INTEL_MKL=ON -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Release ..
make install
```
2. OpenBLAS - CMake should be able to detect the path of OpenBLAS. If it can't, set the `OpenBLAS` environment variable. If using `brew` to install OpenBLAS, set the `OpenBLAS_HOME` environment variable to `/usr/local/opt/openblas/`. To use (with clang):
```
export OpenBLAS_HOME=/usr/local/opt/openblas/
mkdir OPENBLAS && cd OPENBLAS
CXX=/usr/local/opt/llvm/bin/clang++ CC=/usr/local/opt/llvm/bin/clang LDFLAGS=-L/usr/local/opt/llvm/lib CPPFLAGS=-I/usr/local/opt/llvm/include cmake  -DUSE_OPEN_BLAS=ON -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Release ..
make install
```
### (with gcc-6):
```
export OpenBLAS_HOME=/usr/local/opt/openblas/
mkdir OPENBLAS && cd OPENBLAS
CXX=g++-6 CC=gcc-6 -DUSE_OPEN_BLAS=ON -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Release ..
make install
```
I guess @dusenberrymw  had concerns about this PR. If he is OK, we can merge this as our dsl is still experimental. I am also OK with closing this PR for now until we agree on a solution.

I agree with your assessment, only supporting the native backend for Linux is fine. This PR looks good to me :+1:   
You can address my comments in this PR or in a subsequent PR.
